item.title: The Great Waiheke Radio Auckland Central Electorate Candidates Debate
item.description: The Great Waiheke Radio Auckland Central Electorate Candidates Debate. Held at Artworks Theatre on Thurs 28 September, 2023. The candidates were Mahesh Muralidhar (National), Oscar Sims (Labour) and Chloe Swarbrick (Green). Facilitated by Chris Walker.

item.title: Malcolm McMartin And Students At Waiheke Library
item.description: Malcolm McMartin entertained a lively crowd at the library showcasing his primary school students playing all original songs that they’d written, produced and recorded over the past 3 months. The afternoon featured songs from CAT Rockers, Blood Brothers, and Fionn Lawley as well as a few numbers from Malcolm. Later in the hour an interactive session with Malcolm McMartin and members from the audience delighted young and old. Malcolm is a multi-instrumentalist of 30 years who has performed, recorded and toured with original bands and currently teaches bass guitar, guitar, drums and keys.

item.title: THE ANYTHING ARTY SHOW JAN 12 2012
item.description: This week a conversation with Chilean artist Margarita Degorret, a chance to hear from BMW design chief Chris Bangle on cars as art and a run through of the latest movies to play at Waiheke Community Cinema

item.title: Anything Arty Show Jan 5 2012
item.description: This week: Comment on Fiona Pardington’s New Zealand Arts Foundation Laureate Award, Incubator interview with island artist Brett Oakes, Reading from author Rebecca Solnit on her essays The Distance Of Blue from A Field Guide To Getting Lost

item.title: THE ANYTHING ARTY SHOW DEC 15 2011
item.description: This week we heard from Isabel Allende sharing her view of passion and Kara Gordon playing his 35000 year old lancaster guitar

item.description: John Hawkesby interview

item.title: The Anything Arty Show Dec 8 2011
item.description: This week we had conversations with James Clairmont from Waiheke Island Cheese Company on the art of cheesmaking and Elmore Leonard on writing and why he gave up scriptwriting

item.title: The Anything Arty Show November 24th 2011
item.description: This week we heard from Dr. Naif Al-Mutawa talking about his creation The 99 a new breed of comic book heroes. We also heard from Phillipe Starck about his approach to design and Bill Cunniingham on Heels v Flats in Paris and New York

item.title: The Anything Arty Show November 17th 2011
item.description: Another chance to listen to This weeks show with a conversation with Jenny Nicholls of the fabulous new ‘shop’ in Blackpool called Wonderfool. We also had a musical segment of unusual instruments with, amongst other things, a carrot clarinet! We also had a comment from NY street fashion master Bill Cunningham and the final installment of ‘I’m Here I Think Where are You?’ a glimpse into the life of a travelling actor through the letters of Timothy West to to his wife Prunella Scales

item.title: The Anything Arty Show November 10th 2011
item.description: This week we had a conversation with Eve Bon, a new(ish) island artist talking about her passion for art and how that influences her life. We also had our third installment of ‘I’m Here I think Where are You’

item.title: The Anything Arty Show November 3rd 2011
item.description: This week we had excerpts from Icelands Library of Water writers in residence, reading from their work, as well as hapi and hang music, a plug for the movie The Trip and our second instalment of I’m Here I Think Where are You.

item.title: The Anything Arty Show October 27th 2011
item.description: A chance to hear from Geraldine O’Sullivan Beere talking about the words on a Small Island book festival coming up in November, clapping music, Les Barker telling the tale of Spot of the Antarctic and part 1 of I’m Here I Think Where Are You? Letters from Timothy West to his wife Prunella Scales

item.title: The Anything Arty Show October 20th 2011
item.description: This week a world watch conversation with SoJo in Berlin, a conversation with Stéphane Hessel author of the super selling ‘Time For Outrage’ available on the island from Tivoli in Oneroa. Also we had the last episode of our serialisation of Jaws.

item.title: The Anything Arty Show October 13 2011
item.description: This week a conversation with Rhiannon Boelens on Terry Pratchett’s writing, terry Pratchett speaking on assisted dying, some music from Dame Evelyn Glennie and Bjork as well as our second last episode of jaws.

item.title: The Anything Arty Show Sept 29th 2011
item.description: This week we had the second part of a conversation with the Artist Goldsmith, comments from visitors to the new Auckland Art Gallery, info on upcoming palys at Artworks, the 3rd part of the serialisation of Jaws and a comedy song in celebration of my conversations with ‘Arthur’ who died Sunday morning

item.title: The Anything Arty Show Sept 22nd 2011
item.description:
This week we’ve got part 1 of a 2 part conversation with Christine Hafermalz-Wheeler, her husband David, and Bernie Lee of Waiheke based builders, Island 2000 on the creation of a very large installation, Cirtrine, Christine & David’s award winning home.
We also heard from Dominic West on playing some ‘unsavioury’ characters, we had part 2 of our Jaws adaptation and we heard from Bill Cunningham on wedding season in New York.

item.title: The Anything Arty Show Sept 15th 2011
item.description: This week we had a conversation with Island Artist Ingrid Berzins, and heard from Evelyn Glennie and Joseph Phibbs about Phibbs’ ‘Cocktail Concerto’ which premiered at the Cheltenham Festival earlier this year. We also heard a poem from the Tivoli poetry reading held Nov last year and we started a 6 part serialisation of Jaws!

item.title: The Anything Arty Show Sept 8th 2011
item.description: This week amid memory loss and in-attention we managed to hear; Arianna Huffington’s big idea, Sleep To Succeed, Anna Rugis singing songs from her Traffic In Gold CD in the Auckland Art Gallery cafeteria, Krsty Lang talking with author Aravind Adiga about his new book The Last Man In The Tower and a collection of poetry read at an open air reading Nov last year at Tivoli

item.title: The Anything Arty Show September 1 2011
item.description: This week was book week with guest Rhiannon Boelens. Rhiannon talked about two audio books she had recently listened to by Caroline Myss. A medical intuative, Caroline works with archetypes as a process for transformational self change. We also heard the last episode in our adaptation of The Great Gatsby

item.title: Anything Arty Show August 25th 2011
item.description: This week we heard from; Bill Cunningham in New York, Waiheke Artist Barry C Holland, Roger Ingerton Wellington tattoo master and we had the second last episode of The Great Gatsby

item.title: ANYTHING ARTY SHOW AUGUST 18 2011
item.description: Tonight we heard from Chris Saines on the opening of Auckland Art Gallery, Peter Gabriel on his Witness project and Rick Wakeman on the history of Radio Caroline. Also managed a round of ‘Movie Challenge’ and another epsisode of our Great Gatsby serialisation.

item.title: ANYTHING ARTY SHOW AUGUST 11 2011
item.description: This week we had the second part of our conversation with Lyndal Jefferies of teh Red Shed and we heard from Lynda Johnson on the Precious Pieces exhibition running at the Shed. We managed another round of our ‘Movie Trailer Challenge’ and caught up with part 7 of our serialisation of The Great Gatsby

Gatsby’s back next week.

item.title: Anything Arty. Conversation With Elizabeth Eastmond
item.description: A conversation with Tivoli’s Elizabeth Eastmond about The Bash Street Kids exhibitionand a book for a winter read.

item.title: The Anything Arty Show June 16 2011
item.description: This week we were all over the place cramming in as much as I could. We had a report from Asia Down Under on this years Sculpture on the Gulf, another story from Adult Literacy ‘Words 1020’ conversation with Susi Newborm on her way to Goias in Brasil for the screening of Rainbow Warriors of Waiheke in the 13th Film for the Environment Festival (or similar title, it depends which web page you look at) ‘Pick The Film’ competition, movies, music and The Great Gatsby. Phew!

item.title: Anything Arty Show June 9 2011
item.description: This week was book week with reviews of Australian author Kate Morton’s latest book The Distant House and books that had an impact on our childhood, (pop into the library and check out the list) Also movie review of Brighton Rock and a story from the 2010 Adult Literacy group.

item.title: FOREIGN ACCENTS – EMILIA, ACADEMIC IN COMPUTER SCIENCE, FROM RIO DE JANEIRO, BRAZIL. PART 1
item.description:
Emilia worked in Brazil as a software developer before studying for her PhD in UK. From there she moved to New Zealand where she has been living for the last 10 years. Emilia lectures in Computer Science at the University of Auckland – mostly she supervises graduate students and pursues her research, which involves a lot of traveling. Aside from her academic lifestyle we discuss the baffling issue of the lack of female working in computer science in NZ – a cultural issue according to Emilia.
Emilia chose the following tracks to be played: Adriana Calcanhoto – Cariocas Djavan – Meu bem querer Maria Bethania – O meu amor Djavan – Seduzir

item.description: Chilean film maker Matias also plays drums for local band Radio Rebelde. Rollin Guadalupe, Matias’s second full length film, was shot in India, Thailand and New Zealand – come to its world premiere at Artworks on Monday 25th January, 8pm!

item.title: FOREIGN ACCENTS – WITH FOZI, PALESTINIAN FROM SYRIA (PART 2)
item.description:
Palestinian, Fozi was born in Syria where he grew up before moving with his family to Dubai to avoid being conscripted into the Syrian army. Fozi has no citizenship. His visa for Dubai has now expired. He has applied for a refugee status in New Zealand.
Playlist: Amr Diab, Egyptian – Ana ayesh
Fadel Shaker, Palestinian living in Lebanon – Ma’agool
Elissa, from Lebanon – Ajmal Ihsas

item.title: FOREIGN ACCENTS – SAMOA – PART 2
item.description:
Italian-born Renzo works in disaster management and humanitarian aid for Oxfam New Zealand. He left for Samoa the day after the tsunami scoured the south coast of Upolu island. Grant was born and bred in California but his connections with his Samoan family are as strong as if he had grown in his family’s homeland. Both talk about the disaster that struck Samoa in late September.
Playlist from the album “Music from Western Samoa: From Conch Shell to Disco” released in 1982:
Matai of Solosolo & Upolu – Laulau siva
Group of singers and dancers from Upolu villages – Ia lavalava
Matai of Solosolo & Upolu – Vi’i O Solosolo
Apia & Youth Group from Saleufi – Lau lupe
Male musicians of the Catholic Women’s League – Solo

item.title: FOREIGN ACCENTS – SAMOA – PART 1
item.description:
Italian-born Renzo works in disaster management and humanitarian aid for Oxfam New Zealand. He left for Samoa the day after the tsunami scoured the south coast of Upolu island. Grant was born and bred in California but his connections with his Samoan family are as strong as if he had grown in his family’s homeland. Both talk about the disaster that struck Samoa in late September.
Playlist from the album “Music from Western Samoa: From Conch Shell to Disco” released in 1982:
Matai of Solosolo & Upolu – Laulau siva
Group of singers and dancers from Upolu villages – Ia lavalava
Matai of Solosolo & Upolu – Vi’i O Solosolo
Apia & Youth Group from Saleufi – Lau lupe
Male musicians of the Catholic Women’s League – Solo

item.title: The Great Waiheke Comedy Debate
item.description:
Recorded at Palm Beach Resort 3 Aug 2019. Hear Carol Hirschfeld, Sir Bob Harvey, Melodie Robinson, Moana Maniapoto, Danny Codling and Priya Sami arguing for and against: The People’s Independent Republic of Waiheke. The MC was Paul Ego from TV’s 7 Days.
The event was a fundraiser for
two local youth projects:
1. The Waiheke High School kapa haka group trip to Hawaii in April 2020
2. Start up funds for Waiheke Youth 2020 which is a youth-led initiative seeking to professionalise activities on the island which bring confidence and skills to our teenagers who may be struggling with formal education systems. Activities are already happening in this space in an organic way, involving fitness and movement, arts, car mechanics, hip hop and male mentoring. The project seeks to professionalise and scale up the impact proactively engage with young people in a way which enhances their life and employability skills, teaches resilience, and allows young people to see that they have choices in shaping their futures.

item.title: The Great Waiheke Radio Local Board Candidates Debate
item.description:
To conclude our local board election coverage Waiheke Radio hosted a candidates’ meeting at Artworks Theatre on Mon 19 Sept 2016. A couple of notes on this podcast. You will notice that not all candidates answered all questions – they were given the opportunity but some chose not to answer some questions. This was obvious to those in the theatre but we realised after that we hadn’t said that on air. Also, towards the end of the recording gremlins got in and the recording dropped out for a while. Sincere apologies to Paul Walden, whose summing statement is cut off and Cath Handley whose summing up statement is completely missing.
Bob Upchurch and Irene Armstrong both wanted to be at the meeting but had unchangeable prior arrangements and tendered apologies.
Many thanks to Artworks Theatre, the candidates and the people who turned up on the night.

item.title: Matariki At Waiheke High School
item.description:
Matariki at Waiheke High School is by many accounts uniquely celebrated. The school’s four houses spend considerable time learning new waiata and practicing and honing the school haka in preparation for the day’s festivities. These festivities include competetive performances, speeches, and presentations from faculties. The day culminates in the sharing of kai from the hangi that is lit at 4am on the school grounds and feeds over 650 people.
On this 9th year of Matariki at Waiheke High school I recorded part of the Piringakau Kapa Haka group’s performance of “The Legends of Maui”; I also recorded a walk across the campus as houses practiced for the next day’s house competitions. The day of Matariki celebration features recordings of Canto Isola, a speech on the history of Matariki at the school by Whaea Huhana, as well as some house performances of waiata and haka.
Recorded and produced by Brent Simpson.

item.title: Whakanewha Bellbird Release Audio
item.description: On Sunday 16th May 2010 Bellbirds, or Korimako, a rare native New Zealand bird species, were released in Whakanewha Regional Park on Waiheke Island. Waiheke Radio was there to record the event. The programme includes interviews with Park Ranger Andy Spence, Auckland Regional Council chairperson Mike Lee and volunteer John Smeed, a recording of the release of the birds and Mike Lee’s speech detailing the extensive planning and preparation that has gone into this historic occasion.

item.title: Nobilangelo Ceramalus Interview Chris MARCH 8, 2009
item.description: Waiheke Community Board member Nobilangelo Ceramalus is driving a campaign that if successful would see Waiheke secede from Auckland City and become part of Thames Coromandel District Council. The proposal is controversial. While several hundred islanders signed a petition triggering consideration of the proposal by the Local Government Commission there is now a growing number of people speaking out against it. Nobilangleo Ceramalus joined Chris Walker on Island Life to discuss the proposal in an in-depth, and sometimes fiery, interview.

item.title: Boating Show – Pilot
item.description:
Boating Show on Waiheke Radio – Pilot
As part of the Waiheke Radio training course currently being run by Chris Walker, Thomas and Clive have been working on some ideas for a Boating Show on the radio. On Waiheke Island, we are surrounded by water and everyone has experienced boating in one form or another be it on the Ferries, sailing dinghies or larger boats and of course, the recreational fishing. Plenty of boats around Waiheke Island!
In this interview, Thomas talks to Clive about living aboard his boat. This is a Pilot for some of those ideas – if you have any suggestions for boating topics or stories to add, please email us at studio@waiheke.org.nz with the subject line “Boating Show”.

item.description: On Sun 2 Aug 2015 around 60 people gathered to march from Alison Park to Piritahi Marae in support of the campaign to deamalgamate from Auckland Council – Our Waiheke. This short documentary, recorded and produced by Chris Walker captures the sounds and atmosphere of the event.

item.title: Maynie Thompson
item.description:
Maynie Thompson , a staunch activist and proponent of the peace movement, passed away over the weekend, aged 98. In June 2007 it was the 20th anniversary of the passing of legislation to make New Zealand nuclear free. Maynie Thompson was interviewed on Island Life discussing her involvement in the anti-nuclear movement in the 1980s.
Maynie was an amazing woman, on first name terms with both Davis Lange and Helen Clark. In this interview she discussed the inspiration for her involvement in the anti-nuclear movement and some of her adventures as a front line activist.
Waiheke became a hotbed of activism in the eighties and Maynie and other local women found they had plenty of support as they took their message of peace to the world. In 1983 she participated in a march to Wellington calling for the New Zealand government to take a stand on the nuclear issue. Enthused by that experience, a year later Maynie visited Britain to join the womenâs camp at Greenham Common protesting the deployment of American nuclear missiles on British soil. She wasn’t merely a passive participant in this protest, she was involved in cutting the fence and raiding the Greenham Common military complex.
Two years later Maynie again ventured overseas to participate in the Great Peace March across the United States walking much of the way from Los Angeles to Washington DC again calling for peace and an end to the nuclear threat.
Maynie’s activism continued into the 1990s with her participation in the 1995 Peace Flight to Tahiti. This action was to protest French Nuclear testing on the Pacific atoll Mururoa and to lend support to the indigenous people of Tahiti and other Pacific nations who were in the region were the French chose to carry out their nuclear dirty work.
Mayni dedicated many years to the campaign for peace and in this interview she emphasised the overwhelming support she had received from the Waiheke community over this time. She could justifiably look back on her involvement in the peace movement with pride.

item.title: Kunda Dixit – Frames Of War Photo Exhibition, The Press And Democracy
item.description:
Kunda Dixit, publisher of the Nepali Times talks about Frames of War (AUT tower, 5 Rutland Street until the 17th of December), a photoexhibition on Nepal’s Civil War.
He addresses the use of pictures in the post-war reconciliation in Nepal, the challenges of reporting the news, the dangers of self-censorship in newsrooms, and how news organisations can maintain integrity while also selling advertising.
Lastly he talks of the role of Community Radio in Nepal.
He was interviewed on a deck in Oneroa, so apologies for the Waiheke Sounds.

item.title: Hikoi Matiatia
item.description:
On Sunday the 23rd of June 200 people gathered for Hikoi Matiatia, a march from Alison Park to Matiatia protesting against a marina proposed for the bay. Those marching had a diversity of views but were united in their opposition to the marina. This podcast features some of the voices and sounds of the hikoi.
For further Waiheke Radio coverage of the Matiatia marina proposal listen to an interview with the man behind the proposal, Graham Guthrie; Faye Storer on the local board’s position on the proposal; marina opponent Kathryn Ngapo; and an interview with historian and author of a book on Matiatia Paul Monin.

item.title: Denise Roche On The Royal Commission On Auckland Governance
item.description:
Well done Waiheke! A massive community mobilisation saw Waiheke produce a huge number of submissions to the Royal Commission on Auckland Governance. In fact, we make up around only 0.6% of the population of the greater Auckland area but put in around a third of the submissions and forced a hearing of the commission right here on Waiheke.
The majority of submissions from Waiheke emphasised the need for decision making that takes account of our unique local needs. In response the Royal Commission has made the following recommendation.
Waiheke and Great Barrier Island Community Boards should have greater delegated powers than at present, including the management of community halls and reserves, and powers to decide on some local services covered by a budget allocation.
The full report, executive summary and recommendations of the Royal commission can be found here.

item.title: Counting The Beat Silver Scrolls Special 2008
item.description:
The Silver Scrolls are New Zealand’s premier song-writing competition. Run by APRA the awards are based on song-writing rather than any commercial concern. the winner is selected by his or her peers – the other musicians who are members of APRA. The award ceremony is very special because it features performances of all of the finalist songs by other NZ artists. In recent years the awards have also included the admission of an artist into the NZ Music Hall of Fame.
This programme features interviews with some of the finalists and winners of the 2008 awards as well as highlights and performances from the award ceremony.

item.title: Auckland City Councillors Accept The Roger Award 22 May, 2010
item.description:
Waiheke Finally Presented the Roger Award to Auckland City Councillors Cathy Casey, Denise Roche, and Richard Northey at a lively Artworks Ceremony on Saturday.
Amidst much hilarity and some sombreness, the award was finally accepted by the City Vision Councillors on behalf of Auckland City Council.
Denise Roche spoke of conflicts of interest, John of the shenanigans that led to the final decision (unfortunately the recording mechanism failed so you’ll need to see him if you want the gory details).
Cathy Casey spoke poignantly about the personal stress of the campaign and the fear that went with feeling that her emails were being looked at and passed around without her knowledge.
Many spoke of their fears for the new Supercity but some felt these fears may well be opportunities in disguise. Mike Lee spoke of the self-governance opportunities that might arise, Jacinda Ardern spoke of her amendment to the third supercity bill to transfer waste management powers to the Waiheke Community Board. David Clendon spoke of the travesty of justice that the contract was awarded to a multi-national over a local provider.
For most of the people who had joined the fight at various stages the event represented closure and the recognition that although the battle was lost, Waiheke was radicalised into opposition to the Supercity.
See the press release below for additional details.
At this time last year the Waiheke community was in the midst of a battle to preserve its innovative waste management programme. The programme had been widely hailed as a model for the rest of New Zealand, with articles in the major magazines touting the advances made by The Waste Resource Trust and Clean Stream. Waiheke’s campaign to keep its highly successful programme, called Waiheke Does It Better, made news across the country with a music video that circulated on the internet and an appearance on Campbell Live as well as articles in nationwide publications.
Although the C&R-dominated Auckland City Council Community Development Committee ignored its own waste management policy and the stated wishes of the Waiheke Community Board representing island residents by awarding the contract to TPI, some interesting things have come out of it. The term "Mt. Visy", coined by a Waiheke resident, is now the de facto name for the Onehunga MRF. Waiheke’s campaign is also frequently cited in Parliament as an example of poor governmental consultation. TPI meets with a group of Waiheke community members reglualry to montor their progress and see if they can attain the waste recovery percentage that Clean Stream achieved. Waiheke is the only community to enjoy that privilege. And this year, an independent panel awarded ACC the Accomplice Roger Award for the role they played in giving the Waste Tender to the dodgy multi-national, TPI.
The award, however, has yet to be presented. Unsurprisingly, the CDC did not acknowledge receipt of the award. Now, a group of Waiheke Residents, headed by Millie Watkins, have put together an Award Ceremony at Artworks Theatre on 22 May, 2pm, to give the Roger Award presentation its due. The ceremony will be attended by Mike Lee of ARC, Jacinda Ardern, Labour MP and David Clendon, Green Party MP. Denise Roche, Cathy Casey and Richard Northey will be on hand to accept the award on behalf of the rest of the Auckland City Councillors. Two of the Roger Award judges, Joce Jessen and Wayne Hope will officially present the award.
The event on Saturday will close the chapter on the Waiheke Does It Better campaign. Many people put extensive amounts of time and energy into preserving a wildly successful community waste programme, not to mention Clean Stream itself. This Roger Award is for them and the many thousands of supporters on the island and elsewhere. All are invited to come hear the speakers and enjoy refreshments and a cash bar.

item.description: An opportunity to hear an interview with Chris Saines Director of Auckland Art Gallery on the gallery opening in September

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Jonathan Organ – Artist Talk
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Jonathan recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Jonathan Organ and Jessica Pearless, ‘Bunker Vision Hi-Fi’ Jonathan Organ holds a Master of Fine Arts, First Class Honours from Elam School of Fine Arts, University of Auckland. His recent works investigate the perception of surface, specifically analysing optical properties, physical characteristics and perceptions of quality in a controlled body of painted surfaces. Organ has exhibited in New Zealand and internationally, held curatorial positions at a leading auction house and managed prestigious art collections in New Zealand.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Regan Gentry – Artist Talk
item.description:
Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Regan Gentry – Artist Talk
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Regan recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Regan Gentry, ‘Death Row – Rocky Bay Store’ Regan Gentry gained a Bachelor in Fine Arts from Otago Polytechnic School of Art and is now based in Auckland. His practice typically depicts the relationship between people, their environment, and how this is acted out. He has received numerous awards and residencies and his work is represented in a myriad of public spaces and collections including Wellington Botanic Gardens; Connells Bay Sculpture Park, Waiheke Island; Southland Museum and Art Gallery; National Library Gallery of New Zealand and the James Wallace Trust.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Sharonagh Montrose – Artist Talk
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Sharonagh recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Sharonagh holds a PhD, Masters and BFA Hons in Fine Arts from Elam School of Fine Arts, University of Auckland; BSc from Salford University, England and PGCE from Cambridge University. She exhibits nationally and internationally and has works in private collections in New Zealand, Australia, Ireland, England, France, Italy, Croatia, Spain and Kenya.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Veronica Herber – Artist Talk
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Veronica Herber recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Veronica Herber is an emerging Auckland artist. Since graduating from AUT University with a Bachelor of Visual Arts in 2011 her work has been exhibited in the Waitakaruru Sculpture and Arboretum, Hamilton, 2012; Sculpture on the Shore, Devonport, 2012 and in March 2013 she will travel to Australia to install a masking tape work for Cottesloe, Sculpture by the Sea in Perth.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Behind The Scenes With Nansi Thompson & Nicky Cairns
item.description: A chance to hear a conversation with Nansi Thompson Artistic Director of Scultpture on The Gulf 2013 and Nicky Cairns Project Manager. Recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Matthew Muir – Artist Talk
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Matthew Muir recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Waiheke Island-based Matthew Muir completed an MA at the University of Auckland. For the last six years he has been a fll time artist and arts writer. Muir has held six solo exhibitions and contributed work to thirty group shows and other related art events. With a highly distinctive ‘hard line’ painting style influenced by popular culture of the 1960′s-70′s and silkscreen print techniques, the artist reveals influences of Modernism, Pop Art and mass media imagery.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Aaron McConchie – Artist Talk
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Aaron McConchie recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Auckland-based Aaron McConchie holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts from Whitecliffe College of Arts and Design. His practice looks to locate the viewer in both the real and virtual worlds, delving into digital technologies and questioning the proliferation of web based platforms that simultaneously facilitate communication and undermine interpersonal interactions. McConchie has contributed to numerous solo and group exhibitions in New Zealand.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Sarah Brill – Artist Talk
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Sarah Brill recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Sarah gained a Bachelors Degree in Sculpture from Elam School of Fine Arts at the University of Auckland in 1995. She gained a Diploma of Teaching in 1996 and from 1997 Brill has worked full time as an art teacher or professional artist and mother. She is currently teaching at Long Bay College. She has completed large commissioned sculptures for the North Shore City Council, Botany College and her work is held in private collections. In 2011 she won the Estuary Artworks competition organised by the Auckland Council to raise awareness of the Tamaki Estuary.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Kazu Nakagawa & Andrew Caldwell – Artist Talk
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Kazu Nakagawa & Andrew Caldwell recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Born in Tokyo, Kazu Nakagawa has exhibited extensively since immigrating to New Zealand in 1986. His minimalist practices are often based around furniture, architecture or domestic objects, usually incorporating language. His recent works have become more concerned with context and collaboration, creating and inhabiting complex social and physical sites. He is represented in collections nationally and internationally including Australia, England, United States and Japan. He exhibited in the 2003, 2007, 2009 and 2011 headland Sculpture on the Gulf exhibitions.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Delicia Sampero – Artist Talk
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Delicia Sampero recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
German born, Delicia immigrated to Hawkes Bay in 1984, and is now living in Auckland. She has had solo exhibitions in NZ, France, Germany, USA and Samoa. Since 2007 she has focused on collaborations and installations. This includes using “ready-mades” as well as transforming road signs into site-specific art signs/objects to extend the information inherent in this material.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Catwalk Panel Discussion Chaired By Kazu Nakagawa
item.description: A chance to hear again a panel discussion about Catwalk, Winner of the Headland Sculpture on the Gulf 2013 Westpac Selector’s Award. Chaired by Kazu Nakagawa contributors Lisa McEwan, Sharon Evans-Mikellis, Amanda Levey and Amanda Wayers talk about their experience of working on Catwalk

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Anthony Cribb – Artist Talk
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Anthony Cribb recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Anthony is an Auckland-based artist. His practice, primarily in sculpture and installation, works across ideas of scale and site-specificity, material process, participation and duration. He has recently completed a Master of Art and Design at Auckland University of Technology (2010) and is currently working on a PhD. Recent projects (titled by their duration) have included 09/11/2010 – 15/11/2010, St Paul Street Gallery, Auckland; 05/03/2011 – 01/05/2011, Te Tuhi Centre for the Arts, Manukau; 17/03/2012 – 10/06/2012, Waitakaruru Arboretum and Sculpture Park, Hamilton; and 05/09/2012 – 16/09/2012, Ferari, Auckland.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Christian Nicholson – Artist Talk cujimi FEBRUARY 13, 2013
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Christian Nicholson recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Auckland-based multimedia artist Christian Nicholson worked as a designer before switching to art in 2002. Nicholson was a finalist in the Wallace Art Awards in 2007, 2008 and 2009 and eleven of his works are held in the Wallace Collection. He contributed to the 2009 and 2011 headland Sculpture on the Gulf events with Biggie, a sculpture of a life-sized Spitfire, and Barebottomland.

item.title: Headland Sculpture On The Gulf – Jeff Thomson – Artist Talk
item.description:
A chance to hear again the artist talk from Jeff Thomson recorded in the Pavilion at Matiatia on Waiheke Island
Aucklander Jeff Thomson has been a full-time sculptor since 1986 and is unique in having participated in all six headland Sculpture on the gulf exhibitions. During this time he has held solo exhibitions throughout Australia, New Zealand, Germany and France. His favoured material has been corrugated iron, however he also incorporates wire, concrete, plastics, water and other found materials. Thomson holds a BFA in painting from Elam School of Fine Arts, University of Auckland. He was the 1995 Francis Hodgkins Fellow at the University of Otago in 2000, and the Tylee Cottage Artist in Residence, Sarjeant Art Gallery, Wanganui in 2000.

item.title: Island Life 02 July 2016 Zara Strongman Sculpture On The Gulf
item.description: Chris Walker talks to Sculpture On The Gulf director Zara Strongman about the announcement of the artists in the 2017 event.

item.title: Volunteering For Sculpture On The Gulf
item.description: Brent Simpson talks to Xan Hamilton, volunteer co-ordinator for Sculpture On the Gulf

item.title: Who’s The Angel Now?
item.description: Ursula Hoult’s ingenious murder story, WHO’S THE ANGEL NOW?, won her a place in the semi finals of the New York microfiction competition (NYC Midnight) 2019. There were 4000 entries in round one and her story was selected to join the top 20% in the semi-finals.

item.title: Tui Karma
item.description: Rita Ansin’s radio play, TUI KARMA, sprang from a science fiction climate change exercise that required the radio writer to build tension via an element of danger and a change in atmosphere. Rita chose to set her play on Waiheke Island in the near future.

item.title: Thames Frost Fair
item.description: Ursula Hoult’s evocative historical short story, THAMES FROST FAIR, is set to the traditional song Molly Malone, sung by talented local singer, Jean Fraser-Hoult.

item.title: Rock-A-Bye Baby
item.description: Maara White’s radio drama, ROCK-A-BYE BABY, began as an exercise to write a crescendo in sound, beginning with low level sound effects building louder and louder to a final climax. Maara used her own experience when young, pregnant and naked, she survived the 1966 Gisborne earthquake. At both the start and the end of the drama, Maara plays her own instrument, the Koauau.

item.title: Talking Heads: Bed Among The Lentils
item.description:
Waiheke Theatre Company, Artworks Theatre and Waiheke Radio present Talking Heads, a series of audio recordings of the monologues of Alan Bennett, performed and recorded by members of Waiheke Theatre Company.
Bed of Lentils is one of the monologues in Alan Bennetts ‘ Talking Heads’ series. It’s a one woman play produced by Waiheke Theatre Company.
Broadcast on Waiheke Radio Sunday mornings at 11am from Sunday 19 April or available on the Waiheke Radio website
Enjoy the magic of free theatre from the comfort of your couch!

item.title: Saturday Special – Dracula
item.description:
This weeks Saturday Special will leave you shaking in your boots. At 9pm we proudly present Dracula, produced by Waiheke Radio’s very own Neptune Theatre on Air. Don’t miss this phenomenal home-grown production of this blood-curdling classic.
And tune in early, because preceding Dracula we’ll bring you an hour of halloween tunes, from the funny, to the peculiar, to the downright scary.

item.title: Noise Isle
item.description: Chris Walker talks to members of Glass Cell, Death Valley Sweethearts & Body In the Forest about their upcoming show Noise Isle – featuring a track from each band

item.title: Mostly Locally With Timmy Smith
item.description: Today we have Timmy Smith on the show, tune in and listen to Timmy talk jewellery design, park ranger tractor incidents, growing up with a boys name, honouring peoples emotions and having the strength to do what you love. Have a listen Waiheke!

item.title: Mostly Locally With Santa
item.description: Today on the show we are very lucky to have Santa joining us. Have a listen to Santa talking travel at the speed of light, underwear choices for chilly nights, how to avoid elfishness and what the other reindeer really think about Rudolph.

item.title: Mostly Locally With Robyn Manuel
item.description: Listen in to Mostly Locally with guest Dr Robyn Manuel, manager of Hike Bike Ako here on Waiheke. Have an ear as Robyn covers being an academic and her boating connection with the island, her diverse and extensive academic background, being an advocate for Te Reo and its importance to all New Zealanders, cultural tourism on Waiheke and the real history behind why Waiheke is called Waiheke! Its a big show and it covered a heck of a lot of ground!

item.title: Mostly Locally With Rae (Rae) Finlay
item.description: Our guest this week on Mostly Locally is Rae (Rae) Finlay. Rae is a new(ish) full time local but has had a long term relationship with the island and is the Project Director for Sculpture on the Gulf. Have a listen to Rae talking earthquakes, helicopter bungy and what it takes to run Waiheke’s largest event.

item.title: Mostly Locally With Nicola Hambly
item.description: Nicola Hambly joins us on the show today talking insurance, local charity, high school, David Ginola and performing live on stage with David Gilmour (yes THE David Gilmour)..

item.title: Mostly Locally With Tommy “Two Toes” Kendrick And Jake “The Bus” Thornton
item.description: Listen to Tommy and Jake, long term locals talking about how they came to the island and what makes them Waihetians. And some other stuff as well….

item.title: Mostly Locally With Ricky Grounds
item.description: Listen to Ricky Grounds, local business owner, traveler and all round nice guy share a little about his travels and how he got to the island.

item.title: Mostly Locally With David Basham
item.description: This morning on Mostly Locally we have local David Basham talking everything from mental health, platform shoes, 66 years of Waiheke and how to be a decent human being. Thanks for coming on the show David!

item.title: Mostly Locally With James Samuel
item.description: Today we have James Samuel on the show talking food forests, facebook pages, favourite pets, OOOOBY and more. Have a listen Waiheke, its beyond organictastic!

item.title: Mostly Locally With Jess Wallace
item.description: This week on the show we have Jess Wallace, expat Americano, civil engineer, philosopher, educator, everythingnator in fact. Have a listen to a wide ranging conversation and get to know a welcome re-addition to Waiheke Island.

item.title: Mostly Locally With Hilton Galinsky
item.description: Diamond merchant, DJ, Waste Water expert, listen to Hilton Galinsky share a lot about himself and why he loves Waiheke.

item.title: Mostly Locally With Amelia Lawley
item.description: Listen to Amelia Lawley discuss all things Waiheke with host Andy on Mostly Locally

item.title: Mostly Locally With Mike Gray
item.description: Listen in to hear Mike Gray on how he found his way to Waiheke after the Christchurch earthquake, his experience as a comedy writer and stand up comedian, living rough as a vagrant car park dweller, as an entrepreneur and as a valued member of the Waiheke community.

item.title: Mostly Locally With Mike Cox
item.description: Mostly Locally has local Mike Cox as our guest this week. Tune in to hear Mike on Yurts, Sherbert, Oracle and his life journey… as diverse as it gets!

item.title: Mostly Locally With Malcolm McMartin
item.description: Listen in to local Malcolm McMartin talk born again atheism, the deepsouth of NZ and life in rural Invercargil, his love of music and an eclectic bunch of other stuff. Its worth a listen!

item.title: Mostly Locally With Elske-Sanne Hunt
item.description: Mostly Locally – It’s all wine making, coffee roasting, bucket list motorcycling goodness on todays show with guest local Elske Sanne Hunt. The best local hour you will spend this week on Mostly Locally

item.title: Mostly Locally With Denise Whitfield
item.description: Have a listen to local Denise Whitfield talking Japanese, unroped crevasse traversing, walking on waiheke and of course, why Denise loves living on this great island. Dont forget you can book your walks for the festival or volunteer to help here: www.waihekewalkingfestival.org

item.title: Mostly Locally With David Saul
item.description: Have a listen to Dr David Saul on Mostly Locally, covering everything from life on Mars, extreme bacteria, Antartica, forensic genetics, life on Waiheke and his favourite pet. As always its a mixed bag, and a damned interesting bag it is this week!

item.title: Mostly Locally With Cindy Peterken
item.description: Listen to local drama director, sailor, adventurer and teacher Cindy Peterken share some stories of how she came to the island and a whole heap more. Also if you are interested in getting into acting Cindy’s classes and more information can be found here: – https://www.facebook.com/DramabilityWaiheke

item.title: Mostly Locally With Chris Hoff-Nielsen
item.description: Have a listen to Chris Hoff-Nielsen discuss extreme sailing, only packing a tooth brush, the future of electric bikes and running a local e tourism business. Sorry about the missing 5 minutes at around 6m50s, but we pressed on and so does the edited recording.

item.title: Mostly Locally With Chris Bailey
item.description: This week on Mostly Locally we have international award winning artist Chris Bailey on the show. Have a listen to Chis talk everything from boot boys, smashing things up for a living, the age old question of stone or wood, changing life direction and of course the creative process. Its well worth a listen Waiheke!

item.title: Mostly Locally With Bruce Beaumont
item.description: This week on Mostly Locally we have Bruce Beaumont on his move to Waiheke, Fireworks, Dirt Track Racing and life on Waiheke in general. Bring back the trolley derby! Have a listen…

item.title: Mostly Locally With Brendan Moon
item.description: Live from the causeway Brendan Moon is the guest this week offering conversation spanning his time with The Damned, monkfish thermador, local business, John Lydon, and why he loves Waiheke. Just your typical conversation then…

item.title: Mostly Locally With Andre Gonzalez
item.description: A little bit of Brazil on Mostly Locally with Andre Gonzalez the owner of Preto the mens barbers in Oneroa. Have a listen Waiheke, Andre talks everything from death defying motorcycling in his home town of Sao Paulo, how he got into hair, how he lost his, bunking off school to surf, why he is happy every day, how he got to Waiheke and I reckon why we are lucky to have him as a local.

item.title: Mostly Locally With Adam Hunt
item.description: Mostly Locally has Adam Hunt as guest today covering a diverse range of topics, from internet security, land values in NZ, Special Brew snakebites and more!! Have a listen here: –

item.title: Local Govt Commission Says NO To Thames/Coromandel Proposal
item.description:
On Friday 21 Aug the Local Government Commission released it’s decision on the proposal to have Waiheke become part of the Thames / Coromandel District Council. The propoosal was rejected. The full decision can be read here.
This was a controversial proposal, supported by around 1000 petitioners and opposed by hundreds of submitters. The man who developed and pushed the proposal is Nobilangelo Ceramalus, a member of our Community Board, although he was opposed by the remainder of the board on this issue. Mr Ceramalus outlined his reasoning for the proposal in an interview on Waiheke Radio in March.
So what does the man behind the proposal think of it’s rejection? Mr Ceramalus spoke to Kevin Glover on Island Life Sat 22 Aug, the day after the Local Government Commission’s decision was announced.

item.title: Millie Watkins
item.description:
On the 1st of November a new form of Auckland city comes into existance. Before then you’ll have the chance to vote for a mayor, a councillor and a new community board. There are 18 candidates standing for 5 positions on the Waiheke Community Board.
In this first of two opportunities to hear from the candidates Waiheke radio has given each of them two minutes to answer the question, "Why should Waiheke people vote for you?"
After you’ve listened to the statements we encourage you to make comment and ask questions. Later in the election process we will ask each candidate back on-air for an interview which will include your questions. We look forward to your input.

item.title: WASTE – The Battle Is Lost But The War Is Ongoing – Full Council Meeting 12 6 2009
item.description:
Auckland City Councillors in a full meeting of council today, resolved to enter into a 10 year contract with TPI for waste collection as well as operation and redevelopment of the Waiheke transfer station.
In a 10 minute deputation to the councillors, Peta Rickys spoke about how the tender and the process did not meet guidelines laid down in the Hauraki Gulf Marine Act. Sue Connor, of Waiheke Does it Better made it clear that people from Waiheke are disgusted by the process that has been followed. I talked about the fact the Royal Commission suggests a waste management plan for the Gulf Islands and requested that the councillors defer a decision and maintain the status quo, until that, or the Transition Agency for the supercity, was fully functioning.
Councillor Northey suggested an amendment to the resolution which in fact asked for tenders to be reopened, with the existing service continuing until the new tender is agreed to.
Councillors Roche and Casey excused themselves, quoting a conflict of interest. The City Vision Councillors (Crs Nortthey, Boyle, Easte and Fryer) then presented arguments to the effect that consultation had not been followed, the decision was exceedingly unpopular and there could be severe legal repercussions.
Officers John Dutthie, and McQuillan, and CEO David Rankin were asked various questions as to whether protocol had been followed, whether there had been a consultation process, and whether they were satisfied with the financial position of TPI. City Vision councillors also asked about the status of factually incorrect information which had been passed from Aaron Bhatnagar to the press and the defamation implications of this.
It seemed glaringly obvious that Citizens and Ratepayer Councillors were engaged in a tick-box exercise. They were unwilling to consider the social capital and community commitment to a locally based enterprise. Nor would they consider any misrepresentation or wrongdoing on the part of officers in representing the issues.
The amendment was defeated, the resolution was passed.
Cleanstream will no longer control the contract for island waste management, as from 1 July, 2009.
Read more in next week’s papers. The meeting was covered by Liz Waters of the Gulf News.
Express your feelings below on the fact TPI got the contract and Cleanstream were disqualified.
Go to Waihekedoesitbetter.org.nz to look for further commentary and action.
It’s a sad day when democratically elected representatives knowingly make decisions to the detriment of their constitutents and communities.
What I want to know is what do I do with my recyclables if I don’t want them to end up on the Vissy pile?

Someone suggested to me today that the Cory Road pavement upgrade (oh yes, also unpopular) was in fact to make it easier to collect the wheelie bins! Of course for that to happen, the left hand would have to know what the right hand was doing …..

item.title: Vocal Local – Sue Bradford Referendum And Supercity Hearings Waiheke – 6 Aug 2009
item.description:
Sue Bradford talks about being on Waiheke for the supercity hearings, the consequences of her private members bill on child discipline and parental correction, and the current referendum.
For more information http://yesvote.org.nz/ from which the following is taken.
In 2007, by an overwhelming majority of 113 to 8 votes, Parliament granted children protection from assault by their parents. The law is working well but is under threat from a referendum, to be held by postal ballot from 31 July through 21 August 2009.
The issue is too important to ignore, abstain, or spoil your vote. Barnardos, Plunket, Unicef and other child focused organisations all support a YES vote.
Information on Sue Bradford’s Citizens Initiated Referenda (Wording of Questions) Amendment Bill can be found at http://www.greens.org.nz/node/21356
This programme was recorded on 21 July at the supercity hearings.

item.title: Vocal Local – Owhiti Bay – Paora Toi-Te Ranguiaia 12 March 2009
item.description:
I talk to Paora Toi-Te-Ranguiaia about Owhiti Bay. We talk about:
– The importance of the site in archaeological terms
– The relationship between Piritahi Marae and the Ngati and Paoa Trusts
– The importance of the land for Maori
– Paora’s discovery of fossilised shark teeth beads which may be 1,000 years old.
– The reason for the possible change of heart of the Iwi Trust in supporting the development.
– Paora’s desire to record and photograph artefacts found on the island
If you would like to be part of the project please contact Paora at Apex Studio or on 372 5282. You can also contact him on paora@ikonz.co.nz
So what’s your view? Should the development go ahead? Is the coastline unspoilt? Should the ground be protected as an archaeological site?
If you have any thoughts you’d like to share – contact me on findshirin@gmail.com or add to the blog.

item.title: FOREIGN ACCENTS – A 4 MINUTES RETROSPECTIVE
item.description:
The show is essentially about giving a voice to migrants newly arrived in New Zealand, but also to overseas visitors and travelers. I also love to play the music they listen to.
Over the last year I’ve had about twenty guests, all of them Waiheke locals, most of them from a non-English speaking background.
This podcast is a tiny retrospective of the shows. Many of the shows are available on the radio website as podcast.
Happy birthday Waiheke Radio.
Marie-France.

item.title: Jacqueline Carter On Matariki And The Piritahi Marae Celebrations
item.description:
Broadcasting Thursday 25th June at 7pm and Sunday, 28th of June at noon.
Jacqueline Carter talks about the significance of Matariki and the celebrations at Piritahi Marae starting from five on Saturday.
5.00 pm powhiri for new families to the island.
Followed by shared kai, (bring a plate), and story telling and Korero around Matariki.
Bring a sleeping bag and PJs for a sleepover and walk up the maunga behind Piritahi Marae at 6.00 am followed by breakfast organised by the bilingual unit at TeHuruhi school.
If you don’t want to sleep over you can still join the walkers.

item.title: Vocal Local – Mark Parisien On 350 Climate Change And Living On A Boat
item.description:
Broadcast 22 October and replaying 25 October, 12pm.
Mark Parisien, talks about spearheading the 350 climate change initiative on Waiheke. 350 mgs. represents the milligrams of carbon dioxide that the atmosphere can withstand. Any more than that and world temperatures will rise by more than two degrees, causing huge damage to the environment and life on earth.
Mark talks about how this action will be matched by actions around NZ and the world, and will be broadcast in Times Square on the 24th of October.
The Waiheke event – 350 steps for climate change – is a walk from the ACC service centre in Ostend and around the market. People are invited to wear and paint themselves blue and green. Prizes for the most outrageous adult and child outfit. 9.30am for a 10am start.

item.title: Vocal Local – John Stansfield On Recycling, Community And Where To Now
item.description:
John Stansfield, executive director of Clean Stream, talks about community support for Clean Stream, the Transition Agency decision to uphold Council’s decision to award a 10 year contract to TPI, what to do with your recyclables now, as well as engaging with TPI to ensure we have the service we want.
He quotes the latest figures showing that this year Waiheke has achieved a higher diversion from landfill now than in 1997, with a significantly higher population now than we had then.

item.title: Cathy Urquhart – Campaign 4 Fair Ferry Fares
item.description: Cathy talks about the campaign so far and what still needs to be done to get fair fares.

item.title: Campaign for fair ferry fares
item.description:
This goes out on the 12th of February. I talk to Cathy, founding member of the Campaign for Fair Ferry Fares. We talk about the recent reduction in ferry fares on Fullers, quite an achievement as fares have never gone down before.
Until the start of 2009, the ferry providers could set the prices they wanted, provided the routes were not subsidised. This meant that market forces only, determined how the fares are set with potentially devastating consequences to the diversity of our community.
The Transport Management Act introduced this year means that ARTA (the Auckland Regional Transport Authority) now have the capacity to regulate prices on the route. I talk with Cathy about the implications of the Act, how fares can be set fairly, and what needs to be done to ensure they are.
We also talk about the colourful campaigning, involving a coffin protest on Septmeber 1, 2009 when fares were put up last. Listen to the sea shanty at the end of the show or as a separate podcast below. This protest was followed by a Fair Ferry Fairy, and Piracy on the High Seas protest.
The public support for the campaign has been immense, with reporting in the local and national newspapers. We also talk about how the public can participate and support the campaign.
Look out for the Draft Transport Management Plan for Waiheke which is coming up in April – what are your integrated transport solutions to the island?
Links yuu might find useful:
http://fullerswatch.blogspot.com
To comment on the ferries and any problems on journeys (and good things that happen).
http://en-gb.facebook.com/group.php?gid=26919026922 takes you to the "We hate Fullers and their poxy price rise," a spontaneous blog set up by students commuting to the city on Fullers Ferries.
The Campaign for Fair Ferry Fares can be reached on campaign4fairferryfares@gmail.com
To listen to the podcast of the interview click the links below.
If you just want the Fair Ferries sea shanty by Alan Knight and Friends, you can listen to that separately.
Here’s hoping that the introduction of fair fares will make all this community effort redundant in the coming year! Until then … happy campaigning.

item.title: Vocal Local – Basil Holmes On Learning From History
item.description: Basil Holmes, long time Waiheke resident and activist, shares his views on living on Waiheke, the state of the world and what lessons we should learn from the past. In the second half students we meet students and tutors of the programme and talk about their hopes for the future, and what specific activities and skills they’re learning.
Post any poems. thoughts or stories around literacy in the blog entry for this show.
